value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">28</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">nature of Princes; with the arts by which rulers can sway,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">can coax, and can supress. He lives 
            <choice>
              <sic>netirely</sic>
              <corr>entirely</corr>
            </choice> in the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">world of great spirits and great business. The common people</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is contemptible. <quote source="#" rend="inline">"The master of superstition is the 
            <choice>
              <sic>Peopoe</sic>
              <corr>People</corr>
            </choice>.</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Praise <quote source="#" rend="inline">"if it be from the common people, it is 
            <choice>
              <sic>commnoly</sic>
              <corr>commonly</corr>
            </choice></quote></l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>false and naught. The lowest virtues draw 
              <choice>
                <sic>priase</sic>
                <corr>praise</corr>
              </choice> from them;</l>
            <l>the middle virtues work in them 
              <choice>
                <sic>Astonihsment</sic>
                <corr>Astonishment</corr>
              </choice>; and admiration;</l>
            <l>but of the highest vertues they have no sense or 
              <choice>
                <sic>perceibging</sic>
                <corr>perceiving</corr>
              </choice></l>
            <l>at all..."</l>
          </quote>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Even in the delicate grove thought is coloured.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The soul that walked between delicate groves keeps to a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">narrow path between hedges. While <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mmon" key="Montaigne, Michel de">Montaigne</rs> ranged the world.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>micing</sic>
              <corr>mixing</corr>
            </choice> garrulously with everyone, and speculating freely,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-fbac" key="Bacon, Francis">Bacon</rs> kept to the narrow path. Yet even in the shade</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">his thought is embodied. His deep meditations are given 
            <choice>
              <sic>visibe</sic>
              <corr>visible</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">xxxxx concrete form. <quote source="#" rend="inline">"Nay 
            <choice>
              <sic>bretire</sic>
              <corr>retire</corr>
            </choice> men cannot when they would:</quote></l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
              <l>neither will they when it were reason; 
                <choice>
                  <sic>bu</sic>
                  <corr>but</corr>
                </choice> are 
                <choice>
                  <sic>impateint</sic>
                  <corr>impatient</corr>
                </choice></l>
              <l>of privateness even in age and sickness which require the</l>
              <l>Shadow; Like old Townsmen that will still be sitting at 
                <choice>
                  <sic>ther</sic>
                  <corr>their</corr>
                </choice></l>
              <l>street door, though thereby they offer Age to scorn."</l>
            </quote>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" hand="ms" place="margin">
            <quote source="#">
            <l>The <hi rend="underline">colours</hi> that <del hand="ms">show</del> shew best by candlelight, are:</l>
            <l>white, carnation, & a kinde of sea-water green</l></quote>
          </add>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">His contempt was 
            <choice>
              <sic>fr</sic>
              <corr>for</corr>
            </choice> hyperbole; not for the art of speech.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He was teaching the ranting players to speak slowly, closely</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">subtly. He was proving that there is another kind of poetry,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>thepoetry</sic>
              <corr>the poetry</corr>
            </choice> of prose. He was doing his part to bring the 
            <choice>
              <sic>critic</sic>
              <corr>critical</corr>
            </choice> <add hand="ms" place="above">share in bringing the shade</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">faculty into being. <add hand="ms" place="above">prose of the mind</add> He was making an end of anonymity. <add hand="ms" place="above">There by [making?] <!-- come back to this --></add></l>
